title-group.article-title: Detection of Human Papillomaviruses DNA in paired peripheral blood and cervix samples patients with cervical lesions and healthy individuals

abstract.title: Abstract
abstract.p: This study evaluated the presence of HPV DNA in the cervix and peripheral blood of women with cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN I, II, and III) and healthy individuals. Overall, 139 paired peripheral blood and cervix samples of healthy women and women with CIN I, II, and III (n= 68) were tested for HPV DNA by using standard procedures. PCR-sequencing determined HPV types. Quantification of HPV16 E6 and E2 genes was performed to determine viral load and physical state. HPV DNA was detected in the cervix (21.1% in healthy individuals; 48.8-55.5% in CIN patients), blood (46.4% in healthy individuals; 44.1-77.7% in CIN patients), and paired peripheral blood and cervix samples (24% in healthy individuals; 32.5-44.4% in CIN patients). The most frequent types found in the cervix were HPV16, 18, 31, 33, 58, and 70, while HPV16, 18, 33, 58, and 66 were the most frequent types found in the blood. HPV DNA in the cervix was associated with previous sexually transmitted infections (STIs) (P=0.023; OR: 2.978; CI:1.34-7.821), HPV DNA in the blood (P=0.000; OR: 3.369; CI:3.700-18.540), and cervical lesions (CIN I/II or III) (P=0.001; OR: 3.369; CI:1.634-6.945). Binomial Logistic regression showed that HPV DNA in the blood (P=0.000; OR: 9.324; CI:3.612-24.072) and cervical lesions (P=0.011; OR: 3.622; CI:1.338-9.806) were associated with HPV DNA in the cervix. However, we did not find an association between HPV DNA in blood and cervical lesions (P=0.385). Our results showed that, although there is an association between HPV DNA in the cervix with HPV DNA in blood, only HPV DNA found in the cervix was associated with cervical lesions.

I have followed all appropriate research reporting guidelines and uploaded the relevant EQUATOR Network research reporting checklist(s) and other pertinent material as supplementary files, if applicable.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Cervical cancer is the fourth most common malignancy diagnosed in women worldwide, accounting for 6.6% of women’s total cancer cases [1]. Nearly 90% of deaths caused by cervical cancer occur in women from middle and low-income countries [1].

It is well established that persistent infection caused by Human Papillomaviruses (HPV) is involved in cervical and head and neck carcinogenesis [2–9]. Despite the advances in vaccination, treatment, and monitoring, cervical cancer is still a significant cause of death in middle and low-income developing countries [1]. Hence, there is a need for minimally invasive biomarkers to monitor cervical cancer and cervical lesions. Recent studies have shown that circulating free DNA (cfDNA) or circulating tumor DNA (ctDNA) may be useful tools for monitoring cancers caused by HPV [10–16]. In this scenario, several studies have demonstrated the presence of HPV DNA in peripheral blood mononuclear cells [17–25], serum [26,27], and plasma [28–30] from cervical cancer and non-cervical cancer patients. However, despite its importance, few studies evaluate the HPV DNA in paired peripheral blood and HPV DNA in cervix samples from precancerous cervical patients and healthy individuals [21–24,30–32]. Thus, this study evaluated the prevalence of HPV DNA and viral load in paired peripheral blood and cervix samples in cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN I, II, and III) patients and healthy individuals.

sec.title: Patients
sec.p: The paired cervix and blood samples were obtained from women during their gynecological consultation at Hospital das Clínicas, Pernambuco State, Northeast Brazil. The samples were collected from November 2010 to December 2016. A total of 139 women agreed and signed free and informed consent forms. This study was approved by the Ethics and Research Committee (CAAE: 0058.0.106.000-10, HUOC/PROCAPE 64/2010) and (CEP/CCS/UFPE under CAAE: 09307612.8.0000.5208). In this study, 139 paired cervix and blood samples from 71 (51%) healthy individuals, 43 (31%) patients with cervical intraepithelial cervical grade I (CIN I), 16 (11.5%) patients with cervical intraepithelial cervical grade II (CIN II) and 9 (6.5%) patients with cervical intraepithelial cervical grade III (CIN III) were examined. Cervical cancer samples (paired cervix and blood samples) were excluded due to possible metastasis processes.

sec.title: HPV DNA cervix and blood samples
sec.p: DNA from cervical and peripheral blood was extracted using the DNeasy Blood & Tissue Kit (QIAGEN GmbH, Hilden, Germany), following the manufacturer’s instructions. Subsequently, all samples were quantified using a spectrophotometer (NanoVue Plus Spectrophotometer). DNA quality was confirmed by polymerase chain reaction (PCR), which amplifies a fragment of the β-globin gene with the primers described in Table 1.

caption.p: Primers used for PCR amplification, sequencing, and viral load analysis.

sec.p: The presence of HPV DNA was assessed by amplification with two sets of oligonucleotides. The first step was performed with the set of consensus and degenerate primers MY09/11 (Table 1), which anneal in a conserved region of the L1 gene, amplifying a product of approximately 450 bp. Subsequently, nested-PCR was performed using oligonucleotides GP05/06, generating a fragment of approximately 140 bp. The cloned HPV 16 genome and HPV-positive cervical cancer samples were used as positive controls in all PCR reactions. Besides, all tests were performed in triplicate.

HPV-positive samples were genotyped by PCR/sequencing. PCR products were sequenced by the dideoxy-terminal fluorescent method by using the ABI PRISM BigDyeTM Terminator Cycle Sequencing v 3.1 Ready Reaction kit (Applied Biosystems, USA). The sequences were analyzed using the Staden package (STADEN, 1996), with the programs Gap4 (version 4.0) and Pregap4 (version 1.5), which were used to assembly the contigs of the sequences obtained from HPV DNA. After the contig assembly, the BLAST program, available at http://blast.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/Blast.cgi, was used to compare with previously known HPV sequences.

sec.title: Viral load and physical status
sec.p: To determine the viral load and physical status of HPV 16 positive patients, real-time PCR (qPCR) was performed by using the Sybr Green system. For this, seven random paired cervix and blood samples derived from CIN I, II, and III and 12 patients with normal cervical cytology were selected. Viral load was determined from the E6 gene levels present in all patient groups. Each sample’s viral load was expressed as the number of copies of E6 in 50 ng of DNA [33]. A series of dilutions of the complete HPV genome cloned into the pBR-322 vector was carried out to generate the standard curve. Calibration curves for the E2 and E6 genes were created by using the standard dilutions. The DNA extracted from CaSki and SiHa cell lineages was used as a positive control for the reactions. Once calibration curves were constructed for each gene, the samples were analyzed in duplicate. As for physical status, the virus was considered integrated into the host genome when the E2 gene was not detected. To differentiate the episomal form from the mixed form (where there is the presence of both episomal and integrated forms), the E2/E6 ratio was calculated, in which E2/E6 ratio < 1 indicates the mixed form, and values > 1 indicate the predominance of the episomal form [33].

sec.title: Statistical analysis
sec.p: Clinical characteristics were compared between patients with HPV DNA positive and negative in the cervix by using chi-square and Fisher’s exact tests. We performed hierarchical binary logistic regression analysis to identify the variables associated with HPV positive in the cervix, HPV DNA in blood, and cervical lesions. The correlation of viral load of HPV16 DNA in paired cervical and blood samples was examined using the Pearson correlation coefficient test. All P-values were two-sided with a significance level of 0.05, except the Pearson correlation. All data were analyzed using SPSS version 26 (SPSS Inc.Illinois, USA).

sec.title: HPV DNA detection in cervix and blood samples
sec.p: Regarding the cervix or peripheral blood samples, HPV DNA was detected in 50.7% of healthy individuals, 60% in CIN I, 75% in CIN II, and 88.8% in CIN III patients. In contrast, HPV DNA in the cervix was detected in 21.1% of healthy individuals, 48.8% in CIN I, 56% in CIN II, and 55.5% in CIN III patients. In peripheral blood, HPV DNA was found in 46.4% of healthy individuals, 44.1% in CIN I, 50% in CIN II, and 77.7% in CIN III patients. In paired cervix and peripheral blood samples, HPV DNA was found in 24% of healthy individuals, 32.5% in CIN I, 38% in CIN II, and 44% in CIN III patients (Figure 1).

caption.p: Prevalence of HPV in healthy individuals and CIN patients.
Frequency of HPV types found in the cervix and peripheral blood from women of Northeastern Brazil.

sec.p: The most frequently found genotypes in the cervix were HPV16, 18, 31, 33, 58, and 70, while HPV16, 18, 33, 58, and 66 were the most frequently found blood sample types. Globally, the genotypes most frequently found were HPV16 and HPV58 in both cervix and peripheral blood samples. Also, HPV16 was the most frequent genotype in the paired cervix and blood samples (Table 2).

caption.p: Clinical and histological characteristics of patients according to HPV status in the cervix.

sec.p: HPV DNA in cervix were associated with previous STIs (P=0.023; OR: 2.978; CI:1.34-7.821), HPV DNA in blood (P=0.000; OR: 3.369; CI:3.700-18.540) and cervical lesions (P=0.001; OR: 3.369; CI:1.634-6.945) (Table 3). Binomial Logistic regression showed that HPV DNA in the blood (P=0.000; OR: 9.324; CI:3.612-24.072) and cervical lesions (P=0.011; OR: 3.622; CI:1.338-9.806) were associated with HPV DNA in the cervix (Table 4). In contrast, HPV DNA in cervix (P=0.011; OR: 3.918; CI:1.366-11.239) and previous STIs (P=0.002; OR: 28.599; CI:3.574-228.846) were associated with cervical lesions, but not with HPV DNA in blood (P=0.385) (Tables 5 and 6).

caption.p: Best predict model of HPV positive in the cervix
Best predict model of HPV positive in blood.

sec.title: Evaluation of viral load in paired cervix/blood tissues
sec.p: According to the genotyping results, HPV16 was the best candidate to examine the viral load in the paired cervix and peripheral blood samples. Cervix and peripheral blood samples from 12 patients with CIN I, II, and III, and 17 healthy individuals were selected for viral load quantification. Regarding the CIN patients, the viral load varied from 3.65 to 21.58 (E6 copies/cell) in blood and 0.2 to 138 (E6 copies/cell) in the cervix. A correlation was observed between HPV16 viral load present in the cervix and peripheral blood samples in patients with CIN II/III (r=0.65) and CIN III (r=0.60) (Figure 3).

caption.p: Correlation of HPV16 viral load between the cervix and peripheral blood samples. a - Positive correlation of HPV16 viral load between the cervix and peripheral blood samples in CIN III (r=0.6). b-Positive correlation of HPV16 viral load between the cervix and peripheral blood samples in CIN II/III patients (r=0.65).

sec.p: It was also not observed integrated physical status in blood samples from CIN patients. A positive correlation between HPV DNA viral load in cervix and blood was also observed in samples from women with the integrated or mixed virus in the cervix (r=0.64) and in mixed in their peripheral blood (r=0.66) (Figure 4).

caption.p: Correlation of HPV16 viral load between the cervix and peripheral blood samples according to viral physical status. A - Positive correlation of HPV16 viral load between the cervix and peripheral blood samples in women with integrated or mixed viral physical status in cervix (r=0.64). B - Positive correlation of HPV16 viral load between the cervix and peripheral blood samples in women with mixed viral physical status in peripheral blood (r=0.66).

sec.p: Regarding the healthy individuals, the viral load varied from 2.76 to 83.89 (E6 copies/cell) in blood and 0.12 to 246 (E6 copies/cell) in the cervix. The integrated, episomal, and mixed physical status were observed in peripheral blood and cervix samples. There was no correlation between HPV DNA viral load in the cervix and peripheral blood samples in healthy patients.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Here, we investigated the presence of HPV DNA in paired peripheral blood and cervix samples from women with cervical lesions and healthy women. The results showed the presence of HPV DNA in the cervix and peripheral blood samples of both healthy individuals and CIN patients. Our results showed that HPV DNA found in peripheral blood was associated with HPV DNA in the cervix, but not with cervical lesions. Besides, we found a positive correlation between HPV16 viral load in the paired cervix and blood samples in women according to CIN grade and physical status of the virus in the cervix and blood. Therefore, our results showed that, although there is an association between HPV DNA in the cervix with HPV DNA in blood, only HPV DNA found in the cervix was associated with cervical lesions.

Several studies have demonstrated the presence of HPV DNA in peripheral blood mononuclear cells [17–25], serum [26,27], and plasma [28–30] from cervical cancer and non-cervical cancer patients [17–25,27–31,34–36]. According to these studies, the prevalence of HPV DNA in blood ranged from 6.9% to 87%. The studied population, type of lesion, the methodology used to detect HPV DNA, and the specimen type (serum, plasma, and peripheral blood) may reflect the HPV DNA prevalence variation in peripheral blood. In our study, we found a high prevalence of HPV DNA in the blood of patients with cervical lesions from Northeastern Brazil, where diseases caused by HPV are a significant public health concern. Also, we observed a direct relationship between the increase of HPV DNA in blood and the severity of the lesions in patients with CIN I (44.1%), II (50%), and III (77.7%). Similar results were observed in previous studies regarding patients with cervical lesions [28,30]. We used PCR-sequencing to detect HPV DNA in whole peripheral blood and HPV DNA in the cervix. Although PCR-sequencing failed to detect multiple HPV types, this methodology is suitable for HPV DNA detection.

In our study, we detected HPV DNA in peripheral blood. However, we could not distinguish whether HPV DNA is from circulating free HPV DNA or immune cells carrying HPV DNA. Despite the importance, few studies discuss the role of the presence of HPV DNA in the blood of healthy subjects [22,24,32]. HPV DNA has also been detected in pediatric patients [22,37], healthy blood donors [22,23,32], and normal smears [25,30]. Here we observed HPV DNA in 24% of the paired cervix and blood samples from non-cervical lesion patients. When put together, these findings confirm the presence of HPV in blood from subjects with no cervical HPV infection history. However, it is not possible to exclude that the high HPV DNA prevalence in healthy individuals is due to HPV infection in other body sites.

The relationship between HPV viral load and cervical cancer severity is well established. However, few studies evaluated the viral load of HPV DNA in blood from cervical lesions patients. In this study, we observed a positive correlation between the viral load in the paired cervix and blood samples, according to the severity of the lesions (r=0.65, CIN II/III; R=0.6, CIN III), i.e., the viral load in blood increases according to the severity of the cervical lesion. Similarly, a correlation between HPV DNA in blood with the severity or tumor size was also observed in cervical [11,17,27,38–40], head and neck [41–43], lung [20], and breast cancers [44], although a study has failed in finding similar results [30].

One of the HPV-induced process’s key events is the integration of the virus’s genome into the host’s genome [45]. The state of integration is fundamental for the initiation of viral replication. One clue that HPV DNA is integrated into the host genome is the loss of E2. Therefore, absolute quantification of the E2 gene was performed, aiming to determine the viral genome’s physical status in peripheral blood samples from patients with cervical lesions and healthy individuals. Both groups presented predominance of the mixed form. However, previous studies have reported a predominance for integrated [39] and episomal forms [22]. The virus’s presence in mixed form and with a high viral load in healthy individuals reinforces the hypothesis that the virus is carried by the blood cells. Further studies are needed to clarify this aspect.

HPV DNA in peripheral blood has been historically detected in cervical cancer and non-cervical cancer tumors, in which ctHPVDNA migrates from local infection to blood (metastasis) [22]. Furthermore, recent studies have shown cfHPVDNA in the blood of cervical cancer patients [10,27,46]. HPV DNA in the blood of patients with cancer can be originated through apoptosis, necrosis, nucleosomes, phagocytosis, extracellular vesicles, HPV carrier cells, and a combination of these mechanisms [47]. However, the dissemination of HPV DNA from cervical lesions and normal smear still needs to be understood. Our study found HPV DNA in peripheral blood from both patients with and without cervical lesions. However, HPV DNA in blood was associated with HPV DNA in the cervix, but not with cervical lesions. Also, we found a positive correlation between viral load observed in the paired cervix and blood tissues. Hence, we speculated that the virus causes lesions that induce immune responses, predominantly lymphocytic, and then the cells would carry HPV DNA to other body sites through the hematogenous route. Bovine papillomavirus (BPV) cattle infected findings, a model for HPV infection study, support this hypothesis. These findings demonstrate BPV DNA presence in cattle’s peripheral blood with or without warts [48-58] and your presence and activity in lymphocytes [53, 55, 57]. In cattle, studies suggest the blood like a virus reservatory [48, 53-58]. Studies in humans also support this hypothesis. Previous findings demonstrated the presence of HPV DNA in lymphocytes, dendritic cells, NK cells, neutrophils, B lymphocytes CD20+, and CD56+ [23,24].
In conclusion, our results did not show an association between HPVDNA in blood and cervical lesions. However, more studies are needed to clarify the role of HPV DNA in blood and tumorigenesis.

sec.title: Data Availability
sec.p: The authors confirm that the data supporting the findings of this study are available within the article.
